subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] International Quikscript
msgSnippet: ... It s true that Spanish is not a vowel-reducing language, which makes it like Bulgarian or Italian, and unlike Portuguese, Russian, or English. Mexican
messageBody:
Ted Larson Freeman scripsit:

> Yes, I imagine that all languages do have this. I intended my question
> to be about the relative frequency. Teaching myself to write English
> in QS has forced me to pay attention to the details of my own accent
> as never before. I started thinking about more vowel-rich languages
> such as Spanish. It seems to me (although I only studied the language
> in school) that Spanish has less such modification. I started
> wondering if the extent to which spoken languages contain
> emphasis-driven changes in pronunciation is correlated with the
> density of vowels in their phonological structure. My sample is too
> small (and my analysis quite possibly dead wrong) for me to draw any
> conclusions. I was just wondering if anyone knew of any existing
> comparative studies.

It's true that Spanish is not a vowel-reducing language, which makes it
like Bulgarian or Italian, and unlike Portuguese, Russian, or English.
Mexican Spanish may be an exception; in Caribbean Spanish, it's more
about eliding consonants, and all varieties tend to elide intervocalic
/d/ and syllable-final /s/.

--
You're a brave man! Go and break through the John Cowan
lines, and remember while you're out there cowan@...
risking life and limb through shot and shell, http://ccil.org/~cowan
we'll be in here thinking what a sucker you are!
--Rufus T. Firefly
